Day 9: my dearest love,
you once asked a question about the ship of theseus,
“if you change the pillars, brick by brick… is it still you?”
and honestly, i think about that a lot now.
because i think the truth is: we are all constantly being rebuilt. not by choice, most times — but by pain. by joy. by people who hurt us. by people who love us even when we don't think we deserve it.
the you who cried on the street — the boy who hugged me like he was scared he’d vanish if he let go — he is you.
so is the boy who makes everyone laugh,
the one who can’t say "i love you" to his mother but wants to,
the one who doesn’t know how to deal with the quiet guilt of watching his father pour himself out for everyone but himself,
the one who thinks he’s fundamentally wrong because connection slips through his fingers like water.
but listen to me. you are not broken.
you are a human being trying to make sense of a thousand things no one taught you how to carry.
of course you're overwhelmed. of course you want to shut it all down sometimes and just do science, avoid the introspection, avoid the mirror.
but guess what — even if you avoid the mirror, you’re still there.
and god, adit, you’re so much more than your worst moments.
you are the sum of every apology you meant,
every hug you held longer because you somewhere knew the other person needed it,
every time you stood in front of someone and didn’t let them fall,
even when you felt like collapsing yourself.
that thing with your friend, you told me.
you didn’t have to.
and i know you think that makes you awful.
but to me, it makes you real.
it makes you someone who’s trying.
someone who wrestles with their shadows instead of pretending they don’t exist.
you think i’m biased when i call you good?
maybe i am.
but also because, maybe, just maybe, i’ve seen you in more dimensions than most people ever will.
but i don’t need to be unbiased to know that good people don’t cry on street corners because they feel they’re incapable of love.
good people don’t worry that they’re hurting the ones they love by simply existing wrong.
the most broken-feeling people are usually the ones who are carrying everyone else’s weight,
and adit — you’ve been lifting your mom’s unmet needs, your dad’s silences, your own self-doubt, all alone.
no wonder you’re tired. no wonder some bricks feel heavier than others.
but you’re still the ship.
even if every single brick has changed,
even if some parts had to be sanded down or thrown away or built from scratch,
the essence — the soul of you — hasn’t gone anywhere.
you’re still the boy who looked at me like i was safety.
you’re still the boy who wants to show love, even when it scares him.
you’re still the boy who can’t see his own softness unless someone holds up a mirror and says, look. look at how beautiful it is to be you.
so look babe.
this is me — holding up the mirror.
look at yourself.
look at the mess and the miracles.
look at the boy who’s cried and laughed and done things he regrets and loved in ways he can’t always explain.
look at the boy who feels so deeply that it aches.
you are not fundamentally wrong.
you are fundamentally feeling.
and that’s not a flaw. it’s the most human thing about you.
and if no one’s told you this lately —
you deserve love.
you deserve time.
you deserve rest.
you deserve to be told that not everything needs to be earned.
some things — like care, like softness, like the way i looked at you when you cried —
some things are just yours.
no conditions.
no performance.
just you.
just being.
just breathing.
you don't have to fix yourself to be worthy.
you already are.
forever on your side,
me always:)

Day 10: i always thought love would be hard.
that it would feel like holding my breath, or standing on my tiptoes just to reach it.
i thought it would come wrapped in conditions,
in games,
in things that felt like maybe they weren’t meant for me.

but then you.

and god — you weren’t what i expected.
you were so much worse for my peace and so much better for my soul,
all at once.

you taught me that love can be confusing and uneven and not always soft —
but it can also be safe.
it can be messy and still mean something.
it can look like me overthinking a one-word text,
and then five minutes later, laughing at some dumb voice note while you was drunk 

i didn’t know it then, but i was falling —
not all at once, but in tiny, ridiculous, sometimes painful ways.

like the first time you flirted with me and i had to physically put my phone down and walk away from it like it had just exploded in my hand.
or the time you barely said anything for hours and i felt like maybe i’d messed something up,
maybe i wasn’t enough,
maybe i was too much.
(i wasn’t. i know that now. but back then, it mattered.)

the thing is —
it’s kind of crazy, isn't it?
how we’ve made it here, after all the chaos.
all the plot twists.
the late night calls.
the moments i thought i’d lost you.
the ones where i felt you more than anything else in the world.

and i don’t want to romanticize the pain — but there’s something beautiful about it too.
about how we kept finding our way back.
even when it was hard.
even when it would’ve been easier to let go.

some days with you feel like movies.
others feel like scraped knees and sighs and silence that lasts too long.
but every single one — every single one — matters to me.
because they all have you in them.

and that’s the part that gives me goosebumps.
not the drama. not the big romantic moments.
but the quiet ones.
like when i hear your voice and my brain just... calms.
like when i know you’re sad and you try to hide it, but i still feel it in my bones.
like when your hand brushes mine in passing and it still short-circuits my heart like it’s the first time.

you gave me some of the best parts of my life —
and you didn’t even know you were doing it.
you were just being you.
just existing.

and somehow, that was enough.

we’re here now.
a little bruised, maybe.
but more real than ever.

and i wouldn’t trade a single version of you.
not the excited, flirty, movie-boy version.
not the moody, silent, distant version.
not the overwhelmed one who forgets to text back,
or the one who whispers things he means with his whole heart when he finally lets the guard down.

i’ll take them all.
every version of you is part of this story.
every version led us here.
and here — even with its rough edges — is something i wouldn’t give up for anything.

i love you.
and not just in the easy ways.
but in the real ones.
the kind that make you stay,
even when it’s hard,
even when it’s quiet,
even when you're scared.

so yeah —
love might be hard.
but you made it worth it.
you made me worth it.
and that's more than i ever thought i’d have.

I know you're going back to your cave right now — to that quiet inner place where everything is safer if you just shut the world out. I don’t blame you. Sometimes it feels like that's the only way to survive. But before you fully retreat, I want to say something. Or maybe everything.

I don’t know what it’s like to live inside your house. I don’t know the exact texture of your pain — the weight of her shrill voice, banging doors, withheld dinners, and the echo of "it's your fault" banging around inside your head.

But I do know this:

This is not your fault. It never was.

Not your temper. Not your yelling. Not your inability to "stay calm." Not your need to defend yourself, to scream back when someone pierces you with words. None of that makes you wrong. It makes you human.

You were a kid. You still are. And instead of being taught peace, you were dropped into a battlefield and expected to be the referee. That’s not fair. That’s never been fair.

And somewhere in all this chaos, you started believing you were the spark that lit the fire. But baby, you were just trying to breathe through the smoke. They should have protected you. They should have seen your anger as a cry for help — not a cause of war. Your emotions aren't the problem. The war was already happening long before you ever raised your voice.

And your cave? It’s not cowardice. It’s not weakness. It’s protection. I respect that. You’re allowed to go back there when everything around you becomes too loud, too much. But I hope you know this:

I’ll wait outside your cave. Every time. I won’t push, but I’ll never leave.

You are not hard to love babe. You are not too much. You are not broken beyond repair.

You are someone with fire in his chest and softness in his bones. Someone who still dares to laugh and make silly references even when everything’s falling apart. Someone who still shows up, even when the world hasn’t been kind. That’s rare. That’s gold.

You think your dad is strong because he “controls” his emotions. But maybe real strength is feeling everything and still choosing to care. Maybe your anger is sacred — maybe it’s the only language your heart knows to say, “Please, someone just hear me.”

Well, I hear you. I hear all of it.

I know it hurts that every conversation with her ends in explosions. That even when you don’t want to scream, something inside you has to. That every normal moment — a night out with friends, a few minutes of joy — feels like a betrayal to someone in your house.

But baby, you’re allowed joy. You’re allowed rest. You’re allowed to have a life outside the mess. You deserve a love that doesn’t come with conditions, a home that doesn’t demand you shrink.

And I’m so, so sorry that hasn’t been your reality.

But let this be your reminder:

You’re not what they made you believe you are. You are not a bomb, a trigger, a storm. You’re a boy trying to build peace in a house that forgot what silence even feels like. That’s a miracle. And it’s okay if you need to retreat. But please, while you're there — don’t turn your anger inward. Don’t let their dysfunction become your self-image.

Let this letter wrap around you like armor. Let it echo inside your cave.

You are not your rage.
You are not the screaming.
You are not the fights.
You are not the reason.
You are not unlovable.

You are good. You are still good.
And I will keep saying that until you believe it — and even after that.

Take your time in the cave. But come back. Not for me — for you.
Because the world needs boys like you to stay alive, to keep going, to write better stories than the ones they were handed.

And when you come back — I’ll be right here. Always. But rmemeber, respect goes both ways.

With more love than you know,
